How to alternatively create Cotton Candy:

Requirements: Sugar (any type), boiling pan, cotton candy spinner(or something that spins quite fast)

Step 1: Heat up Sugar to melting point,

Step 2: a) Let cool down on stick you choose to use. b)dump the sugar into spinner

Step 3: for a) let stick spin in spinner until desired amount. for b) wait until all is spun then insert stick to grab Cotton Candy.

There you go, an alternative way to the videos if you want very sugary and bland cotton candy

(Make sure to clean up)

I actually used one of these in the past, and I found that the results were best with stuff that's uniform and can be ground down easily in a mortar and pestle.

- I had the best results with granulated sugar (as you showed)- I had about the same results with butterscotch candies and round hard peppermint disks.  Grinding these into powder first improved the uniformity of the texture afterwards. I found that the unground discs melt at a different rate and cause thicker strands which are slightly crunchy, are about the size of fishing line, and do not mesh well with the rest of the cloud, hence the reason to grind the candy beforehand.- Strangely, pixie sticks or other powdered candy didn't seem to do as well and instead gummed up the mechanism in the center

I hope this is helpful for those of you who may be trying this as well :D

I have this hard candy cotton candy machine.
- If you put too many pieces of candy, or too much sugar at the same time, it comes out in clumps, and can even burn.
- Having an uneven balance of candy pieces doesn't really seem to affect it.
- You DO NOT need to crush them for it to work.
- You absolutely have to let it heat up EVERY TIME you add new candies, or sugar.
- Not all hard candies handle the same in the machine. I found that some "sugar free" candies worked better than their normal counterparts from the same companies.

I actually did this about 8 years ago during an internship after my first year of culinary school. They had the industrial machines to so it made it a bit easier than the small household machines that are on the market.
